knowledge_relations.extra: Wiki references source file: e:\university_lms\[admin\books\[id]\edit\page.tsx](file:\e:\university_lms\app\admin\books\[id]\edit\page.tsx) - *Added in commit ee597f7*

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Display Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the book display component hierarchy in the university_lms application. Explain how BookOverview and BookList serve as container components that orchestrate the presentation of multiple BookCard instances. Detail the composition pattern where BookCard renders BookCover and BookCoverSvg for visual representation. Document the props interface between these components, including the Book type from types.d.ts. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how sample book data from constants/index.ts is passed through the component tree. Illustrate the responsive layout strategies used in BookList and BookOverview for different screen sizes. Address common customization points such as modifying card styling or extending book metadata display. Include best practices for reusing and extending these components for new book-related views.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sign-in Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sign-in flow implementation in the university_lms application. Explain how the /sign-in route is structured using Next.js App Router within the (auth) route group and rendered within the shared AuthLayout. Detail the integration between page.tsx and the reusable AuthForm component, including prop passing and mode configuration. Document the use of React Hook Form with the login validation schema from lib/validations.ts, focusing on email and password field rules. Explain error handling and feedback mechanisms for invalid credentials or server responses. Include a practical example showing form submission handling and success redirection logic. Address security aspects such as input sanitization, protection against common attacks, and potential integration with authentication providers like OAuth or JWT-based sessions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Overview Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookOverview component, which displays the featured book on the homepage. Explain its role in highlighting a single prominent book using a large visual layout. Document how it consumes the Book interface from types.d.ts and retrieves sample data from constants/index.ts. Describe its composition using BookCard for consistent styling and data presentation. Include practical examples from the codebase showing prop usage, responsive design considerations, and integration with the main page layout. Address common customization needs such as changing the featured book dynamically or styling adjustments. Explain performance implications of image loading and rendering optimizations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Overview Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookOverview component in the university_lms application. Explain its role as a featured book showcase at the top level of the homepage, highlighting how it selects and displays a prominent book from the sample data in constants/index.ts. Document the component's props, focusing on its use of the Book interface from types.d.ts. Provide a concrete example from the codebase showing how it renders a single BookCard with enhanced visual treatment. Illustrate how responsive design is implemented using Tailwind CSS classes to adapt layout across device sizes. Address customization options such as changing the featured book selection logic or modifying the presentation style. Include best practices for integrating BookOverview into other high-level layouts and potential performance considerations when scaling to dynamic data sources.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Card Props Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookCard component's props interface in the university_lms application. Define the expected Book object structure as defined in types.d.ts and used in BookCard.tsx, including fields such as title, author, coverImage, availability, rating, and any additional metadata. Explain each prop's type, purpose, and whether it is required or optional. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how the Book interface is imported and used within BookCard. Document any TypeScript best practices applied, such as using readonly modifiers or discriminated unions if present. Illustrate how prop validation is enforced at compile time and how missing or incorrect props would be handled. Address common issues like undefined data rendering and strategies to prevent runtime errors using optional chaining or default values.

wiki_catalogs.name: Fine Calculation Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Fine Calculation Workflow. Document its purpose, implementation details, data models, component architecture, and integration patterns. Include the fine calculation algorithm, user interface components, and workflow automation. Provide practical examples and troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rate Limiting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Rate Limiting system. Document its purpose, implementation details, configuration (5 requests per minute), Redis integration, and user experience when limits are exceeded. Include the technical architecture, error handling, and security benefits.

wiki_catalogs.name: Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Session Management system. Document its JWT strategy, token lifecycle, callback implementations (jwt and session), security considerations, and integration with NextAuth. Include the session data structure, expiration handling, and client-side access patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the university_lms application. Detail the core frameworks: Next.js 15.5.2 for routing and rendering, React 19.1.0 for component architecture, and TypeScript for type safety. Explain the role of each dependency: React Hook Form and Zod for form validation, Tailwind CSS with shadcn/ui for utility-first styling, and Radix UI for accessible primitives. Document configuration specifics from next.config.ts (image optimization), tailwind.config.ts (custom themes and fonts), and tsconfig.json (module resolution). Provide version compatibility information and development tooling (ESLint, PostCSS). Include practical examples showing how these technologies integrate, such as the cn utility from lib/utils.ts combining Tailwind classes. Address setup considerations and performance implications of the chosen stack.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication component system in the university_lms application. Thoroughly explain the implementation of AuthForm.tsx as a reusable component that dynamically adapts to sign-in and sign-up use cases through props. Document its integration with React Hook Form and Zod validation schemas from lib/validations.ts, including error handling and form state management. Detail the interface between page-level components in app/(auth) and the shared AuthForm, including onSubmit callback patterns. Provide concrete examples from sign-in/page.tsx and sign-up/page.tsx showing how the same component is configured differently for each flow. Explain the AuthCredentials interface from types.d.ts and its role in type safety. Address common issues such as validation error display, loading states, and form reset behavior. Include guidance on extending the form for additional authentication methods or fields.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sign-up Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sign-up flow implementation in the university_lms application. Describe how the /sign-up route is organized under the (auth) route group and uses the same layout as sign-in for consistent UX. Explain how the AuthForm component is configured in 'signup' mode to render appropriate fields and validation rules. Detail the Zod schema in lib/validations.ts for registration, including name, email, password, and confirmation requirements. Illustrate the form state management using React Hook Form, highlighting real-time validation and error display. Provide a code example demonstrating submission handling and response processing. Discuss data integrity considerations, password strength enforcement, and potential extension points for email verification or CAPTCHA integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book List Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookList component responsible for rendering a collection of books. Explain how it maps over book data from constants/index.ts and public/books.json to generate multiple BookCard instances. Document the data flow from static JSON files to React components, including type safety via the Book interface in types.d.ts. Provide examples of how the list handles responsive grid layouts using Tailwind CSS, manages loading states, and ensures accessibility. Discuss performance considerations such as virtualization potential, key prop usage, and re-render optimization. Include guidance on extending the component for filtering, searching, or sorting functionality in future implementations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book List Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookList component in the university_lms application. Explain its purpose as a container for rendering multiple BookCard components in a responsive grid layout. Document how it imports and maps over the sample book collection from constants/index.ts, passing each book object as props to individual BookCard instances. Detail the component's structure, including its use of Tailwind's grid system for responsive behavior across breakpoints. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing data flow from BookList to BookCard, including prop types defined in types.d.ts. Address common usage patterns such as filtering, sorting, or paginating the book list. Include guidance on customizing the grid layout, extending functionality for search integration, and optimizing rendering performance for large collections.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Cover Visual Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the integration of BookCover and BookCoverSvg components within BookCard. Explain how BookCard composes these visual elements to render a stylized, 3D-like book cover representation. Document the conditional logic used to determine which cover component to render based on data availability or display context. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how props are passed from BookCard to BookCover components, including image URLs, fallback states, and accessibility attributes like alt text. Illustrate the styling coordination between components using Tailwind CSS classes and shared utility functions from lib/utils.ts. Address customization options such as modifying the cover aspect ratio, adding animations, or supporting new image formats. Include performance considerations when rendering multiple covers in a list, such as lazy loading or image optimization techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the component architecture of the university_lms application. Explain the component hierarchy and composition patterns used throughout the codebase. Detail how high-level components like BookOverview and BookList compose lower-level components such as BookCard and BookCover to create rich UIs. Describe the container-presentational pattern evident in the separation of data handling from display logic. Analyze the reusable AuthForm component that serves both sign-in and sign-up flows through prop configuration. Document the Header component's navigation logic and active route detection using usePathname(). Include practical examples from the codebase showing component relationships and props usage. Address best practices for component creation and extension within this architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the navigation component in the university_lms application. Explain the implementation of Header.tsx including its use of Next.js usePathname() hook for active route detection and dynamic link styling. Document the component's structure with navigation links to key sections like Home and Library. Detail its integration with RootLayout in app/layout.tsx and app/(root)/layout.tsx, including how it wraps page content. Provide concrete examples from page.tsx showing the header in context. Explain the responsive design considerations for different viewport sizes. Address customization options for adding new navigation items or modifying the header's appearance. Include best practices for maintaining accessibility and SEO in navigation components.

wiki_catalogs.name: AuthForm Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AuthForm component, a reusable UI element that dynamically adapts to both sign-in and sign-up use cases. Explain its implementation using React props to toggle between modes, conditionally rendering fields and adjusting validation schemas accordingly. Document the integration with React Hook Form for state management and Zod for schema validation, referencing the loginSchema and registerSchema from lib/validations.ts. Detail the form submission handler and how it abstracts API calls for different authentication actions. Include a practical example showing how parent pages pass configuration via props. Address accessibility features, error messaging strategies, and extensibility for additional authentication methods like social logins or two-factor authentication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Card Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookCard component, which represents an individual book in both BookOverview and BookList. Explain its props interface based on the Book type from types.d.ts, including title, author, availability status, and cover image URL. Document its internal composition using BookCover and BookCoverSvg for visual presentation with 3D-like styling effects. Include practical examples showing how BookCard is reused across different contexts with consistent styling via Tailwind classes. Address accessibility features, hover effects, and responsive behavior. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like broken images or layout shifts. Highlight extensibility points for adding actions like 'Borrow' buttons or tooltips.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Card Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookCard component in the university_lms application. Explain its role as the primary presentation unit for individual books within lists and overviews. Document how it receives a Book object (from types.d.ts) as a prop and renders structured information including title, author, availability, and rating. Detail its composition pattern, specifically how it embeds BookCover and BookCoverSvg for visual representation of the book's cover art. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing the component's implementation with conditional rendering for availability status. Illustrate responsive styling using Tailwind classes and interaction states like hover effects. Address customization points such as adding new metadata fields, modifying the visual layout, or integrating click handlers for navigation. Include best practices for reusing BookCard in different contexts and performance tips for rendering large lists.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling and Responsive Layout
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the styling implementation of the BookCard component, focusing on its responsive layout and interactive states. Explain how Tailwind CSS utility classes are used to create a flexible, grid-friendly card with hover effects, focus states, and dark mode compatibility. Document the use of the cn utility function from lib/utils.ts for dynamic class composition and merging Tailwind classes safely. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing responsive breakpoints, padding/margin strategies, and typography scaling. Illustrate how the component adapts to different container sizes in BookList versus BookOverview contexts. Address customization points such as modifying color schemes, adjusting spacing, or adding new interaction states. Include best practices for maintaining accessibility and performance when applying complex styling to multiple cards in a list.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the authentication system in the university_lms application. Explain the implementation of sign-in and sign-up flows using Next.js App Router with route groups under (auth). Detail how the shared AuthForm component handles both use cases through conditional rendering and form configuration. Document the integration of React Hook Form with Zod validation schemas from lib/validations.ts to ensure input correctness. Explain the AuthCredentials interface defined in types.d.ts and its role in type safety. Include practical examples showing form state management, error handling, and validation rules. Address security considerations and potential extension points for connecting to real authentication services.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Primitives and Utilities
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the UI primitives and utility functions in the university_lms application. Explain the shadcn/ui-based component library in components/ui and how these low-level primitives (button, form, input, label) are used to build higher-level components. Document the cn utility function in lib/utils.ts that combines clsx and tailwind-merge for robust class composition. Provide concrete examples showing how these primitives are imported and used in components like AuthForm.tsx and BookCard.tsx. Explain the benefits of this approach for maintaining consistent styling and accessibility. Address customization options through Tailwind configuration and component extension patterns. Include best practices for using these utilities to avoid common styling conflicts and ensure responsive behavior.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Validation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the form validation system used across authentication flows in the university_lms application. Focus on the Zod-based validation schemas defined in lib/validations.ts, including AuthCredentials interface alignment, field-level constraints (email format, password strength, name length), and error message customization. Explain how these schemas integrate with React Hook Form through zodResolver for runtime type safety and seamless validation feedback. Illustrate schema reuse between login and registration forms, highlighting shared and unique rules. Provide examples of validation error handling in the UI and strategies for user-friendly feedback. Discuss extensibility for internationalization, dynamic validation rules, and testing validation logic.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Data Model and Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Book interface defined in types.d.ts. Detail each field including title, author, isbn, publicationYear, genre, availability status, coverImageUrl, and description. Explain how this interface ensures type safety across the application. Document the sample data implementation in constants/index.ts and public/books.json, including structure consistency and validation practices. Include examples of valid and invalid data entries to illustrate constraints. Discuss future considerations for extending the model with additional metadata like borrower information or due dates. Provide guidance on maintaining data integrity when integrating with external APIs or databases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Cover Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BookCover and BookCoverSvg components in the university_lms application. Explain their combined role in creating a visually engaging 3D-like book cover representation within BookCard. Document how BookCover acts as a wrapper that applies perspective and shadow effects using Tailwind CSS, while BookCoverSvg renders the actual book artwork as an SVG with dynamic color and text from the parent BookCard. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how these components are composed and how props are passed from BookCard. Illustrate the responsive behavior and aspect ratio preservation across different screen sizes. Address customization options such as modifying the SVG design, changing the perspective effect, or supporting image-based covers. Include best practices for maintaining visual consistency and performance optimization when rendering multiple covers on a page.

wiki_catalogs.name: Usage Patterns and Composition
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the usage patterns of the BookCard component across different contexts in the university_lms application. Explain how BookCard is reused within BookList for rendering collections and within BookOverview for featured displays. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how parent components pass data and handle events like clicks or borrows. Document the data flow from constants/index.ts or public/books.json through BookList/BookOverview down to BookCard. Illustrate any conditional rendering logic based on user authentication state or book availability. Address best practices for efficient rendering of large lists using React keys, memoization with React.memo if applicable, and virtualization considerations. Include guidance on extending BookCard for new use cases, such as adding action buttons or integrating with future API calls.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the book management system in the university_lms application. Explain how books are displayed and organized through components like BookOverview (featured book), BookList (collection), and BookCard (individual items). Detail the Book interface in types.d.ts that defines the data structure including title, author, availability, and cover image. Document the source of book data from constants/index.ts and public/books.json. Include practical examples showing how book data flows from static sources to UI components. Explain the visual design choices for book presentation, including the 3D-like BookCover component. Address data consistency, performance considerations for rendering lists, and future integration with dynamic data sources.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing and Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the routing and navigation system in the university_lms application. Explain the Next.js App Router structure with route groups (auth) and (root), and how layout.tsx files provide shared UI across routes. Detail the RootLayout and AuthLayout implementations and their role in organizing page structure. Document the Header component's navigation menu and how it uses usePathname() to highlight active routes. Include practical examples showing the relationship between file structure and URL routes, such as /sign-in mapping to app/(auth)/sign-in/page.tsx. Address best practices for adding new routes and maintaining layout consistency across the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the styling strategy in the university_lms application. Explain the utility-first approach using Tailwind CSS and how it's configured in tailwind.config.ts with custom themes, fonts (IBM Plex Sans, Bebas Neue), and dark mode support. Detail the global styles defined in globals.css and their role in establishing base typography and layout. Document the cn utility function in lib/utils.ts that combines Tailwind classes using clsx and tailwind-merge. Explain the shadcn/ui component pattern in components/ui and how these primitives are extended for application-specific needs. Include practical examples showing class composition and theme customization. Address responsive design implementation and accessibility considerations in the styling system.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on state management patterns in the university_lms application. Explain how React state is used for form handling in AuthForm with React Hook Form managing input states and validation. Detail navigation state management in Header using usePathname() to determine active routes. Document the use of utility functions in lib/utils.ts for derived state like conditional class composition. Include practical examples showing state flow from user interaction to UI updates. Address the absence of global state management libraries and how component-local state suffices for current needs. Discuss potential scalability considerations if the application grows to require more complex state sharing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on data management in the university_lms application. Explain the current approach using static data files: constants/index.ts for sample book data and public/books.json for additional book information. Detail the Book interface in types.d.ts that provides type safety for data structures. Document the data flow from these sources to components like BookList and BookOverview. Include practical examples showing how data is imported and rendered in the UI. Address the limitations of static data and outline potential integration points for future API-based data fetching. Discuss data consistency, validation, and performance considerations for rendering book collections.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the development setup for the university_lms application. Provide step-by-step instructions for environment configuration, including Node.js version requirements and dependency installation using npm. Document development commands from package.json such as 'dev', 'build', and 'lint'. Explain key configuration files: tsconfig.json for TypeScript settings, next.config.ts for Next.js-specific options, and tailwind.config.ts for styling. Include practical examples showing how to start the development server and run tests. Address common setup issues and their solutions, such as dependency conflicts or configuration errors. Provide guidance on code structure conventions and development workflow best practices.

wiki_overview.content:
# Comprehensive Analysis of University LMS Project ## 1. Project Introduction ### Purpose Statement The University LMS (Library Management System) is a Next.js-based web application designed to manage university library resources. Marketed as "ShelfWise," the system provides students and faculty with an intuitive interface to browse, search, and borrow books from the university's collection. ### Core Goals and Objectives - Provide a modern, responsive interface for library resource discovery - Implement secure authentication for university members - Display comprehensive book information including availability status - Facilitate borrowing operations through a digital interface - Create a scalable foundation for future library management features ### Target Audience - University students needing access to academic resources - Faculty members requiring research materials - Library administrators managing book inventory and user accounts - University IT staff responsible for system maintenance ## 2. Technical Architecture ### Component Breakdown The application follows a component-based architecture built on Next.js 15.5.2 with React 19, utilizing modern frontend technologies: - **Core Framework**: Next.js App Router for server-side rendering and routing - **Styling**: Tailwind CSS with custom theme configuration and shadcn/ui components - **State Management**: React Hook Form with Zod validation for form handling - **UI Components**: Reusable component library with clear separation of concerns ### Design Patterns The project implements several modern design patterns: - **Component Composition**: Complex UI elements built from smaller, reusable components - **Container-Presentational Pattern**: Separation of data-fetching components from display components - **Form Abstraction**: Generic AuthForm component that adapts to sign-in/sign-up use cases - **Theme System**: CSS variables with Tailwind's dark mode support and custom color palette ### System Relationships ```mermaid flowchart TD A[Client Browser] --> B[Next.js App Router] B --> C[Authentication Layer] B --> D[UI Components] C --> E[AuthForm] E --> F[React Hook Form] F --> G[Zod Validation] D --> H[Book Components] H --> I[BookCard] H --> J[BookOverview] H --> K[BookList] I --> L[BookCover] D --> M[Header] M --> N[Navigation] ``` ### Data Flow ```mermaid flowchart TD A[User Interaction] --> B[React Component State] B --> C[React Hook Form] C --> D[Zod Validation] D --> E[Form Submission] E --> F[Server Actions/API] F --> G[Database] G --> H[Data Response] H --> I[Component Re-render] I --> J[Updated UI] ``` ## 3. Implementation Details ### Main Entry Points The application has two main layout structures: one for authentication routes and another for authenticated users. **Root Layout** - The top-level layout that wraps all pages: ```tsx const RootLayout = async ({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) => { return ( {children} ); }; ``` Sources: - [layout.tsx](e:\university_lms\app\layout.tsx#L34-L46) **Authenticated Layout** - Wraps the main application interface: ```tsx const layout = ({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) => { return (
{children}
); }; ``` Sources: - [layout.tsx](e:\university_lms\app\(root)\layout.tsx#L4-L16) ### Core Modules #### Authentication System The authentication system uses a flexible component that adapts to both sign-in and sign-up flows: ```tsx const AuthForm = ({ type, schema, defaultValues, onSubmit, }: Props) => { const isSignIn = type === "SIGN_IN"; const form: UseFormReturn = useForm({ resolver: zodResolver(schema), defaultValues: defaultValues as DefaultValues, }); // ... }; ``` The form validation is handled by Zod schemas defined in the validation library: ```tsx export const signInSchema = z.object({ email: z.string().email(), password: z.string().min(8), }); ``` Sources: - [AuthForm.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\AuthForm.tsx#L25-L94) - [validations.ts](e:\university_lms\lib\validations.ts#L10-L14) #### Book Management Components The book display system is composed of several interconnected components: **BookOverview** - Displays detailed information about a featured book: ```tsx const BookOverview = ({ title, author, genre, rating, total_copies, available_copies, description, color, cover, id, }: Book) => { return (

{title}

By {author}

Category {genre}

{/* ... */}
{/* ... */}
); }; ``` **BookList** - Renders multiple books in a grid: ```tsx export const BookList = ({ title, books, containerClassName }: Props) => { return (

{title}

    {books.map((book) => ( ))}
); }; ``` **BookCard** - Individual book representation: ```tsx const BookCard = ({ id, title, genre, color, cover, isLoanedBook = false, }: Book) => (

  • {title}

    {genre}

    • ); ``` Sources: - [BookOverview.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\BookOverview.tsx#L4-L73) - [BookList.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\BookList.tsx#L7-L24) - [BookCard.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\BookCard.tsx#L4-L48) ### Configuration Approach #### Next.js Configuration The application configures image optimization for external book covers: ```tsx const nextConfig: NextConfig = { images: { remotePatterns: [ { protocol: "https", hostname: "placehold.co", }, { protocol: "https", hostname: "m.media-amazon.com", }, ], }, }; ``` Sources: - [next.config.ts](e:\university_lms\next.config.ts#L3-L18) #### Tailwind CSS Configuration The project uses a comprehensive Tailwind configuration with custom themes: ```tsx export default { darkMode: ["class"], content: [ "./pages/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}", "./components/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}", "./app/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}", ], theme: { extend: { fontFamily: { "ibm-plex-sans": ["IBM Plex Sans", "sans-serif"], "bebas-neue": ["var(--bebas-neue)"], }, colors: { primary: { DEFAULT: "#E7C9A5", admin: "#25388C", }, // ... additional color definitions } } }, plugins: [require("tailwindcss-animate")], } ``` Sources: - [tailwind.config.ts](e:\university_lms\tailwind.config.ts#L1-L115) #### TypeScript Configuration The TypeScript configuration enables modern JavaScript features and module resolution: ```json { "compilerOptions": { "target": "ES2017", "lib": ["dom", "dom.iterable", "esnext"], "allowJs": true, "skipLibCheck": true, "strict": true, "noEmit": true, "esModuleInterop": true, "module": "esnext", "moduleResolution": "bundler", "resolveJsonModule": true, "paths": { "@/*": ["./*"] } } } ``` Sources: - [tsconfig.json](e:\university_lms\typescript.json#L1-L27) ### External Dependencies The project leverages several key dependencies: ```json "dependencies": { "@hookform/resolvers": "^5.2.1", "@radix-ui/react-label": "^2.1.7", "@radix-ui/react-slot": "^1.2.3", "class-variance-authority": "^0.7.1", "clsx": "^2.1.1", "lucide-react": "^0.542.0", "next": "15.5.2", "react": "19.1.0", "react-dom": "19.1.0", "react-hook-form": "^7.62.0", "tailwind-merge": "^3.3.1", "zod": "^4.1.5" } ``` The integration of React Hook Form with Zod validation creates a robust form handling system: ```tsx const form: UseFormReturn = useForm({ resolver: zodResolver(schema), defaultValues: defaultValues as DefaultValues, }); ``` The UI components leverage shadcn/ui patterns with Radix UI primitives and utility functions: ```tsx function Button({ className, variant, size, asChild = false, ...props }: React.ComponentProps<"button"> & VariantProps & { asChild?: boolean }) { const Comp = asChild ? Slot : "button" return ( ) } ``` Sources: - [package.json](e:\university_lms\package.json#L1-L38) - [button.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\ui\button.tsx#L40-L59) ### Component Relationships ```mermaid graph TD A[RootLayout] --> B[Authentication Routes] A --> C[Root Routes] B --> D[AuthForm] D --> E[React Hook Form] E --> F[Zod Validation] C --> G[Header] C --> H[BookOverview] C --> I[BookList] H --> J[BookCover] I --> K[BookCard] K --> J K --> L[Button] G --> M[Navigation Links] J --> N[Image] L --> O[Shadcn UI Base] O --> P[Radix UI Primitives] O --> Q[Tailwind Utilities] Q --> R[cn function] R --> S[clsx] R --> T[tailwind-merge] ``` ## 4. Key Features ### Functionality Overview The University LMS provides several key features: - **Authentication System**: Secure sign-in and registration with form validation - **Book Discovery**: Browse and search library collection with detailed book information - **Visual Book Display**: Attractive book covers and metadata presentation - **Responsive Design**: Mobile-friendly interface that adapts to different screen sizes - **Themed UI**: Custom color scheme with potential dark mode support ### Implementation Highlights #### Dynamic Font Loading The application implements custom font loading using Next.js font optimization: ```tsx const IBMPlexSans = localFont({ src: [ { path: "/fonts/IBMPlexSans-Regular.ttf", weight: "400", style: "normal" }, { path: "/fonts/IBMPlexSans-Medium.ttf", weight: "500", style: "normal" }, { path: "/fonts/IBMPlexSans-SemiBold.ttf", weight: "600", style: "normal" }, { path: "/fonts/IBMPlexSans-Bold.ttf", weight: "700", style: "normal" }, ], }); ``` Sources: - [layout.tsx](e:\university_lms\app\layout.tsx#L5-L20) #### Conditional Class Composition The application uses a utility function for conditional class names: ```tsx export function cn(...inputs: ClassValue[]) { return twMerge(clsx(inputs)) } ``` This enables clean conditional styling in components: ```tsx
  • ``` Sources: - [utils.ts](e:\university_lms\lib\utils.ts#L3-L7) - [BookCard.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\BookCard.tsx#L4-L48) #### Sample Data Structure The application uses a well-defined TypeScript interface for book data: ```tsx interface Book { id: number; title: string; author: string; genre: string; rating: number; total_copies: number; available_copies: number; description: string; color: string; cover: string; video: string; summary: string; } ``` Sources: - [types.d.ts](e:\university_lms\types.d.ts#L1-L41) ### Usage Examples #### Rendering Book Collections ```tsx const Home = () => ( <> ); ``` Sources: - [page.tsx](e:\university_lms\app\(root)\page.tsx#L5-L15) #### Navigation Structure ```tsx const Header = () => { const pathname = usePathname(); return (
    • Library
    ); }; ``` Sources: - [Header.tsx](e:\university_lms\components\Header.tsx#L8-L36) ### Feature Architecture ```mermaid stateDiagram-v2 [*] --> Authentication Authentication --> SignIn: User navigates to /sign-in Authentication --> SignUp: User navigates to /sign-up SignIn --> Validation: Form submission SignUp --> Validation: Form submission Validation --> Success: Valid credentials Validation --> Error: Invalid input Success --> Dashboard: Redirect to main application Dashboard --> BookBrowse: User interacts with book components BookBrowse --> BookDetail: Click on book card Error --> Authentication: Display error message ``` The application architecture demonstrates a clean separation of concerns with well-defined component responsibilities and data flow patterns. The use of modern Next.js features, TypeScript typing, and utility-first CSS creates a maintainable foundation for a university library management system.

wiki_readme.content:
This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

## Deploy on Vercel

The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.

Check out our [Next.js deployment documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying) for more details.

## What we use

- Extensions: ESLint, Prettier, Rainbow Bracket, ES7+ React/Redux/React-Native snippets, Tailwind CSS IntelliSense


- Next js 15.5.2
- React 19
- Tailwind CSS v3 3.4.16
- Shadcn 3.0.0
- - Button
